title: Chipotle is targeting the top of the K-shaped economy
summary:
Chipotle Mexican Grill plans to raise menu prices by 1-2% this year — and leadership is betting that its core consumer segment, digital natives who earn over $100k, won't mind.
Speaking during Tuesday's fourth-quarter earnings call, CEO Scott Boatwright said Chipotle is focusing on boosting foot traffic and revenue amid weak comparable sales.
To do that, they're targeting their core customer, who sits firmly at the top end of the K-shaped economy.
The broader restaurant segment is struggling with slumping sales as the K-shaped economy has upended the typical playbook for value deals and marketing campaigns.
Boatwright added that Chipotle will continue to test ideas to keep consumers coming back, including more limited-time offers and drink innovations.

title: Jobs reports delayed, because government shutdown
summary:
Ben Casselman reporting for the New York Times:The Bureau of Labor Statistics will not release monthly jobs numbers on Friday as scheduled because of the partial government shutdown, said Emily Liddel, an associate commissioner for the bureau.
The report, one of the most closely watched economic indicators each month, would have provided data on job growth, unemployment and wages in January, as well as annual revisions to employment estimates from 2024 and 2025.
The report “will be rescheduled upon the resumption of government funding,” Ms. Liddel said.
A report on job openings and turnover in December, scheduled for release on Tuesday, will also be delayed.

title: The 37 Rising Stars Shaping the Future of Venture Capital in 2026
summary:
The era of easy money in venture capital is over, and a new generation of investors is rising in its place.
After years dominated by easy money and sky-high valuations in AI startups, the venture industry has shifted toward sharper judgment, tougher diligence, and startups that can actually scale into businesses.
We also solicit recommendations from the broader venture community and past Rising Stars, and make several selections of our own based on deal flow, reputation, and impact over the past year.
The investors on our 2026 Rising Stars of Venture Capital list come from a wide range of backgrounds and roles, including associates, principals, and founding partners.
Now meet the rising stars of venture capital, listed alphabetically.

title: Energy Transfer Leans Into Income Growth With Distribution Hike And Pipeline Spend
summary:
Energy Transfer (NYSE:ET) has raised its regular quarterly cash distribution by more than 3%.
Management has outlined a target of 3 to 5% annual distribution growth going forward.
Energy Transfer, which operates a large network of midstream energy assets, sits at the heart of moving oil, gas and related products across key US regions.
Stay updated on the most important news stories for Energy Transfer by adding it to your watchlist or portfolio.
Alternatively, explore our Community to discover new perspectives on Energy Transfer.

title: Jeff Bezos-owned WaPo launches 'substantial' layoffs and shuts down its sports department
summary:
Impact LinkThe Washington Post, owned by billionaire Amazon founder Jeff Bezos, is conducting widespread layoffs.
Executive editor Matt Murray wrote in a Wednesday memo that the "substantial newsroom reductions" would impact "nearly all news departments."
The layoffs impacted hundreds of workers, according to a spokesperson for the Washington Baltimore News Guild, which represents the newsroom's union.
In his memo, Murray wrote that for the immediate future, the paper would concentrate on "areas that demonstrate authority, distinctiveness, and impact and that resonate with readers."
The Post's staff reductions arrive at a challenging moment for the media industry.

title: Here's the severance package The Washington Post is offering laid-off staffers
summary:
Hundreds of journalists at The Washington Post received dreaded emails in their inboxes on Wednesday morning informing them they'd been laid off.
The emails also addressed another key question: how much severance the Post was offering.
The company also must negotiate separation terms with the newsroom's union, the Washington Post Guild.
The Washington Post did not immediately respond to a request for comment from Business Insider.
Outside of severance, Post workers may also receive financial support from a new GoFundMe page launched on Wednesday that has raised over $100,000, including $10,000 from Kara Swisher.

title: Jobs, cash, loans: Can Bangladesh’s parties deliver on election promises?
summary:
From loans to scholarships for foreign studies, Bangladesh’s main parties are wooing the youth.
With election campaigning under way across the country, he is now hearing promises aimed squarely at people like him: cash support or interest-free loans for the jobless, and sweeping job-creation targets.
When asked about cash support or interest-free loans for unemployed graduates, Rafi chuckled.
In the current fiscal year, the government allocated about 400 billion taka (roughly $3.2bn) for agriculture, fisheries, livestock and food security.
For Rahman, the contest moving on is not only about big promises, but whether a new government can deliver without straining the economy.
